content: The Act titled "True American Heroes Act of 2003" authorizes Congressional Gold Medals for government workers who responded to and perished in the attacks on the World Trade Center. The "True American Heroes Act of 2003" authorizes Congressional Gold Medals to be presented to officers, emergency workers, and employees of government agencies who responded to and perished in the 9/11 attacks, with arrangements made by the Speaker of the House and the President pro tempore of the Senate. The "True American Heroes Act of 2003" authorizes Congressional Gold Medals to be presented to officers, emergency workers, and employees of government agencies who responded to and perished in the 9/11 attacks. The Secretary of the Treasury will design and strike gold medals with suitable emblems for the recipients, consulting with relevant authorities. Duplicates of the medals will be struck for display in respective offices and stations. The "True American Heroes Act of 2003" authorizes Congressional Gold Medals to be presented to officers, emergency workers, and employees who responded to and perished in the 9/11 attacks. The medals will be displayed in various offices, stations, and places of employment, including precinct houses, fire houses, and emergency response stations, in memory of the individuals. The "True American Heroes Act of 2003" authorizes Congressional Gold Medals to be presented to individuals who responded to and perished in the 9/11 attacks. Duplicates in bronze of the gold medal can be struck and sold under regulations set by the Secretary. The medals should ideally be struck at the United States Mint at West Point, New York. Congressional Gold Medals authorized for individuals on United Airlines Flight 93 who resisted hijackers and caused the crash. On September 11, 2001, United Airlines Flight 93 was hijacked by terrorists and crashed near Shanksville, Pennsylvania after passengers resisted the hijackers. United Airlines Flight 93 crashed prematurely after passengers resisted hijackers, potentially saving many lives and important symbols of democracy. The leaders of the resistance showed exceptional bravery and patriotism, deserving Congressional Gold Medals for their heroic service. The Secretary of the Treasury will strike gold medals for individuals who resisted hijackers on United Airlines Flight 93. Duplicate bronze medals may also be sold to cover costs. Congressional Gold Medals will be awarded to government workers who responded to the Pentagon attacks and perished. Gold medals will be presented to officers, emergency workers, and employees of the US Government who responded to the Pentagon attacks on September 11, 2001. The design of the medals will be determined by the Secretary of the Treasury. The Secretary of the Treasury will determine the number of medals and recipients after consulting with the Secretary of Defense and other relevant officials. SEC. 104. NATIONAL MEDALS are national medals under title 31, United States Code. The Congress acknowledges the tragic events of September 11, 2001, where over 6,000 people lost their lives in terrorist attacks in New York City, at the Pentagon, and in Pennsylvania. Emergency personnel responded heroically, and the nation united in support of the victims and their families. The civilized world stands against such cowardly acts of terrorism. The Congress acknowledges the tragic events of September 11, 2001, where over 6,000 people lost their lives in terrorist attacks in New York City, at the Pentagon, and in Pennsylvania. Emergency personnel responded heroically, and the nation united in support of the victims and their families. The minting of coins in commemoration of the Spirit of America will pay tribute to the countless heroes who risked their lives during the attacks and in their aftermath, and to a united people whose belief in freedom, justice, and democracy has never wavered. SEC. 202. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue $50 gold coins weighing 1 ounce with 91.67% gold, $1 silver coins weighing 26.73 grams with 90% silver, and half dollar clad coins. The Secretary will mint half dollar clad coins weighing 11.34 grams with a diameter of 1.205 inches. The number of gold coins minted shall be 25,000 plus a determined amount based on consultation with specific officials. The Secretary will mint $50 coins to honor innocent individuals killed in the 9/11 attacks. The coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. Only metals from natural deposits in the US can be used for minting. Special treatment is allowed under exigent circumstances. The Congress acknowledges the effectiveness of limitations on commemorative coins to stabilize markets and maximize demand. Special treatment is permitted in exigent circumstances, such as the events of September 11, 2001. The Congress recognizes the importance of quickly implementing a coin program to raise funds for the victims of the September 11, 2001, attacks. Therefore, coins produced under this program are exempt from certain limitations on commemorative coins. The design of coins minted under this title shall commemorate the events of September 11, 2001, with specific inscriptions and symbols. The Secretary will select the design in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts. Coins minted under this title will be issued in uncirculated quality, except for $50 gold coins which will be issued in proof quality. Only one facility of the United States Mint may be used to strike a particular quality of coins, except for half dollar coins which can be struck at any number of facilities. The Secretary will start issuing coins soon after the enactment of this Act and will stop issuing coins after one year. Coins will not be issued after the 1-year period from the initial issuance date. Coins will not be issued after the 1-year period from the initial issuance date. Sale of coins is regulated under SEC. 205. The Secretary sells coins at a price including face value, surcharges, and design costs. Bulk sales are offered at a discount, and prepaid orders receive a reasonable discount. Gold coins are exempt from certain regulations. The Secretary sells coins at a price including face value, surcharges, and design costs. Bulk sales are offered at a discount, and prepaid orders receive a reasonable discount. Gold Coins: The Secretary shall issue a 50 dollar coin for presentation to the next of kin or personal representative of identified individuals. The Speaker of the House of Representatives and the President Pro Tempore of the Senate will arrange for the presentation of such gold coins on behalf of Congress. SEC. 206. Surcharges on sale of coins. The Secretary shall impose surcharges on coin sales to cover production costs, with minimum amounts set for different coin denominations. Excess proceeds will be used to cover production costs of all coins issued under this title. The Secretary imposes surcharges on coin sales to cover production costs, with excess proceeds used for production costs of all coins. Any remaining amount is transferred to a fund for victims of the September 11, 2001 tragedies as determined by the Secretary of the Treasury and the Attorney General.
